contentrichtext.text: {{Expand Chinese|秦腔|date=May 2013}} [[File:YisuQing.jpg|thumb|right|250px]] [[Image:China-Shaanxi.png|thumb|right|200px|Map showing location of Shaanxi province in China]] '''Qinqiang''' (秦腔, [[pinyin]]: Qínqiāng) or '''Luantan''' ([[wikt:亂彈|亂彈]], [[pinyin]]: Luàntán) is the representative folk [[Chinese opera]] of the northwest Province of [[Shaanxi]], China,<ref>{{cite news |title=China promove programas diversificados durante o Festival da Primavera |author= |newspaper=[[China Radio International]] |date=February 8, 2008 |url=http://portuguese.cri.cn/135/2008/02/08/1@83413.htm |accessdate=November 17, 2010}} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fportuguese.cri.cn%2F135%2F2008%2F02%2F08%2F1@83413.htm English])</ref> where it was called [[Qin (state)|Qin]] thousands of years ago. Its melodies originated from rural areas of ancient Shaanxi and [[Gansu]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Chinese opera The First Emperor transmitted live into theaters worldwide |author= |newspaper=[[People's Daily]] |date=January 14, 2007 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/200701/14/eng20070114_341080.html |accessdate=November 17, 2010}}</ref> The word itself means "the tune or sound of Qin".<ref>{{cite book |title=Miraculous response: doing popular religion in contemporary China |last=Yuet Chau |first=Adam |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2006 |publisher=Stanford University Press |location= |isbn= |page=53 |pages= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=6puW1nI2o7EC&pg=PA53&dq=qinqiang#v=onepage&q=qinqiang&f=false |accessdate=November 17, 2010}}</ref> The genre uses the ''bangzi'' (woodblock) as one of the accompanying instruments, from which it derives its other name, ''Bangzi opera''. Bangzi tune is the oldest, most affluent opera tune in China's [[Four Great Characteristic Melodies]]. Qinqiang is the representative of the Bangzi opera and the most important origin of other Bangzi operas.<ref>{{cite book |title=Women of China |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2001 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=q52yAAAAIAAJ&q=qinqiang&dq=qinqiang |accessdate=November 17, 2010}}</ref> [[Tan Dun]], the composer for the opera [[The First Emperor]], researched Qinqiang for the opera, in order to learn more about "ancient Chinese vocal styles".<ref>{{cite news |title=Tan Dun's Operatic Odyssey |author=Matt Dobkin and Ken Smith |newspaper=[[Playbill]] |date=December 6, 2006 |url=http://www.playbillarts.com/features/article/5701.html |accessdate=November 17, 2010}}</ref> ==History== Qinqiang was banned from "being performed in Beijing" in 1785 by the emperor at the time, [[Qianlong Emperor|Qianlong]]. It was stated that "the sexual suggestiveness of the genre" was the reason for it being banned, but it is believed that the real reason was because the difference in style from prior Chinese folk opera styles allowed [[Social criticism|social critique]] of China to be written into them. The ban, however, only ended up expanding the style into more areas outside of Beijing, primarily to theatres in the southeast.<ref>{{cite book |title=Soul of Beijing Opera: Creativity and Continuity in Modern Performance |last=Ruru |first=Li |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2010 |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |location= |isbn= |page=36 |pages= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-vA7w3e1YR0C&pg=PA20&dq=qinqiang#v=onepage&q=qinqiang&f=false |accessdate=November 17, 2010}}</ref> ==Characters== There are 13 kinds of characters in Qinqiang including four kinds of "[[Sheng of Chinese opera|Sheng]]" (生, male)(老生、須生、小生、幼生), six kinds of "[[Dan (Chinese opera)|Dan]]" (旦, female)(老旦、正旦、小旦、花旦、武旦、媒旦), two kinds of "[[Jing of Chinese opera|Jing]]" (淨, painted face male)(大淨、毛淨) and one kind of "[[Chou of Chinese opera|Chou]]" (丑, Clown), also knowns as " 13 Tou Wangzi" (十三頭網子). ==Actors== *[[Wei Changsheng]] ==Repertoire== * ''Sandixie'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.qinqiang.com China Qinqiang Website] (Chinese) {{Shaanxi topics}} [[Category:Culture in Shaanxi]] [[Category:Chinese opera]] {{china-music-stub}}
